uncertainty_register.unknown: HYPERSCALER PARTNER AGREEMENT TERMS: Actual AWS, Azure, Google partner agreements including: (1) Partner credit/rebate rates and tier qualifications (exact % and volume thresholds), (2) Agreement duration and termination provisions (can hyperscalers terminate with 30 days notice? 90 days? requires cause?), (3) Minimum volume commitments and penalties for non-performance, (4) Exclusivity or competitive restrictions, (5) Price protection or most-favored-nation clauses, (6) Change of control provisions (M&A impact on partnership status), (7) Renewal terms and conditions. Partner agreements are NON-DISCLOSED - not in public filings, not referenced in detail.
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: FUNDAMENTAL BUSINESS VIABILITY ASSESSMENT: If hyperscaler agreements can be terminated with 30 days notice for any reason, Public Cloud business ($1,683M, 61% of revenue) has ZERO CONTRACTUAL PROTECTION and could be eliminated overnight. If agreements have minimum volume commitments and Rackspace is failing to meet them (customer churn reducing volumes), may already be in breach triggering credit reductions or termination. If agreements require exclusive focus on one hyperscaler, limits Rackspace's multi-cloud strategy. AFFECTS: (1) Valuation - acquirer must understand partnership stability and contractual rights, (2) Retention risk - if partnerships are month-to-month, existential risk is immediate not theoretical, (3) Strategic flexibility - volume commitments or exclusivity constrain Rackspace's ability to pivot or reposition. CRITICAL FOR DUE DILIGENCE: Any serious acquirer will demand full partner agreement disclosure in exclusivity phase - inability or refusal to provide complete agreements would be deal-killer.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: ACCESS: Request from management complete copies of: (1) AWS partner agreement (reseller and consulting partner terms), (2) Azure CSP 2-Tier agreement, (3) Google Cloud partner agreement, (4) Any amendments, side letters, or supplemental agreements, (5) Latest renewal documentation showing current terms and expiration dates. LEGAL REVIEW: Have counsel review for: (1) Termination rights and notice periods, (2) Volume commitments and current performance vs requirements, (3) Change of control provisions affecting M&A, (4) Exclusivity or competitive restrictions, (5) Economic terms (credit rates, fee structures) and how they compare to industry standard MSP partner agreements. BENCHMARK: Compare Rackspace terms to other large MSPs (if comparable data available from competitors' IPO filings or acquisition disclosures). RISK QUANTIFICATION: Model scenarios for: (A) Partnership termination (what notice period, what immediate impact), (B) Credit reduction (if credits drop 5%, what profit impact), (C) Volume commitment shortfall (if failing to meet minimums, what penalties or tier changes).

uncertainty_register.unknown: VMWARE (BROADCOM) LICENSING COSTS AND CONTRACT TERMS: Actual VMware licensing spend ($ annually), contract terms and expiration dates, Rackspace's options for: (1) Refusing price increases (can Rackspace continue on old pricing, for how long?), (2) Reducing VMware footprint (flexibility to scale down licenses as Private Cloud revenue declines), (3) Migrating to alternatives (contractual barriers vs operational barriers), (4) Renegotiating terms (is Broadcom willing to offer discounts to prevent customer loss?). Current VMware pricing crisis post-Broadcom acquisition: What is Rackspace's ACTUAL cost increase (% and $), when did it take effect, what options does Rackspace have?
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: PRIVATE CLOUD VIABILITY DETERMINATION: If VMware costs increased 200-300% and Rackspace MUST ABSORB (cannot pass to customers, cannot migrate off VMware), Private Cloud segment gross margin compresses from 38.6% to estimated 25-30% or worse. At 25% margin on $1,055M declining 13% YoY, segment contributes $263M gross profit declining to $220M, then $190M - may drop below breakeven after allocated overhead within 2-3 years. If VMware costs increased but Rackspace CAN MIGRATE to alternatives (OpenStack, Hyper-V) over 2-3 years, provides strategic option to escape vendor lock-in (though migration risk remains high). AFFECTS: (1) Segment profitability forecasting, (2) Private Cloud strategic decision (defend and invest vs harvest and exit), (3) Customer pricing decisions (how much VMware cost to pass through vs absorb), (4) Acquisition attractiveness (acquirer inherits same VMware dependency unless can negotiate better terms or has alternative platform). WITHOUT KNOWING ACTUAL VMWARE COST IMPACT, CANNOT MODEL PRIVATE CLOUD ECONOMICS.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: ACCESS: Request from management: (1) VMware licensing spend 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025 (Q1-Q4 trend showing when Broadcom price increase took effect), (2) VMware contract terms: expiration dates, termination provisions, flexibility to reduce licenses as customer base shrinks, (3) Broadcom negotiations: Has Rackspace engaged Broadcom to negotiate relief? What was outcome? (4) Alternative platform migration plan: If one exists, what's timeline, cost, risk assessment? (5) Customer price pass-through: Has Rackspace increased Private Cloud pricing to cover VMware costs? What % passed through vs absorbed? What customer reaction/churn? CALCULATE: Net margin impact: If VMware was $X in 2022, now $Y in 2024, delta = $(Y-X) compressing gross profit by that amount. At $1,055M revenue with 38.6% margin = $407M gross profit. If VMware increased $100M, new margin = ($407M - $100M)/$1,055M = 29% (compressed 960bps). If VMware increased $200M, new margin = 19.6% (compressed 1,900bps). MATERIALLY IMPACTS VALUATION.

uncertainty_register.unknown: PARTNER REVENUE CONCENTRATION: What % of Public Cloud revenue is AWS vs Azure vs Google, what % of Private Cloud is VMware vs OpenStack vs Microsoft Hyper-V, which partners does Rackspace depend on most heavily. If Public Cloud is 70% AWS, 20% Azure, 10% Google, then AWS partnership is DISPROPORTIONATELY CRITICAL (AWS termination eliminates 43% of total Rackspace revenue vs 12% if Azure terminates). If Private Cloud is 80% VMware, 15% OpenStack, 5% Hyper-V, then VMware dependency even more severe than assumed.
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: PARTNER CONCENTRATION RISK QUANTIFICATION: Determines whether partner risk is DISTRIBUTED (no single partner >30% of revenue) or CONCENTRATED (single partner >50% of revenue creating single-point-of-failure). If AWS represents 40-50% of total revenue, AWS has effective VETO POWER over Rackspace's existence - can eliminate majority of business by terminating partnership. Acquirer would demand specific AWS partnership protections or guarantees before closing. If VMware represents 30-35% of Private Cloud (only portion using VMware platform), VMware price shock is serious but not existential - can migrate non-VMware customers separately. AFFECTS: (1) Valuation discount for partner concentration (10-20% discount if single partner >40% of revenue), (2) Deal structure (acquirer may demand partnership assignment guarantees or renewals as closing condition), (3) Strategic repositioning priorities (reduce concentration by building alternative platform capabilities or exiting concentrated segments).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: ACCESS: Request from management: (1) Public Cloud revenue breakdown: % AWS, % Azure, % Google, % other cloud providers (2022-2024 trend), (2) Private Cloud technology platform breakdown: % VMware vSphere, % OpenStack, % Microsoft Hyper-V, % other (2022-2024 trend), (3) Partner contribution to total revenue: Rank partners by % of total Rackspace revenue they enable (AWS 40%, VMware 30%, Azure 15%, Google 8%, etc.), (4) Customer multi-cloud adoption: What % of Public Cloud customers use multiple hyperscalers (AWS+Azure+Google) vs single hyperscaler - determines customer flexibility and partner negotiating leverage. ASSESS: If concentration is >40% in any single partner, that partner has existential control. If distributed <30% each, concentration risk is manageable. RECOMMEND: Diversification strategy if concentration excessive (build out underweight partners, migrate customers across platforms to balance).

uncertainty_register.unknown: FEDRAMP AUTHORIZATION STABILITY AND CHANGE OF CONTROL IMPACT: FedRAMP authorization status (currently active? any deficiencies or findings requiring remediation?), exact change of control provisions (what triggers review? who is acceptable acquirer? what is re-authorization timeline and process?), FedRAMP JAB or Agency-specific authorization (JAB is harder to get but more valuable, Agency authorizations are easier but less portable), contingency plans if authorization at risk (can Government customers be migrated to alternative Rackspace entity or must go to competitors?).
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: M&A FEASIBILITY AND GOVERNMENT SEGMENT VALUE: If foreign acquirer automatically INVALIDATES FedRAMP with no re-authorization path, eliminates 60-70% of potential acquirer pool (all European, Asian, Middle Eastern buyers excluded). Government segment ($270-410M estimated revenue, $70-145M estimated profit) has ZERO VALUE to foreign acquirer - must be carved out or sold separately. If domestic acquirer triggers 12-18 month re-authorization with HIGH CUSTOMER LOSS RISK (50%+ of customers migrate rather than wait), Government segment value is heavily discounted (must haircut by expected customer loss + re-authorization costs + business disruption). If authorization is currently UNSTABLE (pending findings, deficiencies, at risk of suspension), Government segment may have NEGATIVE VALUE (liability due to compliance costs with limited revenue runway). AFFECTS: (1) Acquirer universe (foreign vs domestic), (2) Government segment valuation (full value vs discounted vs carved out), (3) Transaction structure (single buyer vs multiple buyers for different segments), (4) Closing conditions and timeline (re-authorization required pre-close vs post-close risk). CRITICAL: This is likely BIGGEST M&A CONSTRAINT - most acquirers are foreign (PE firms, strategics outside US) and cannot maintain FedRAMP.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: ACCESS: Request from management: (1) Current FedRAMP authorization status: JAB or Agency? Expiration date? (2) Recent 3PAO assessment results: Any findings? Open POA&Ms (Plan of Action & Milestones)? Risk of suspension? (3) Change of control documentation: Exact contractual/regulatory language on what triggers review, who is acceptable acquirer, (4) FedRAMP discussions: Has Rackspace consulted with FedRAMP PMO on hypothetical change of control scenarios? What guidance provided? (5) Customer contract provisions: Do Government customer contracts have clauses allowing termination if authorization lost? What notice periods? (6) Historical precedent: Have other FedRAMP providers successfully transferred authorization through M&A? What was process and timeline? LEGAL OPINION: Engage FedRAMP compliance counsel to opine on: (A) Foreign acquirer feasibility (realistic vs impossible), (B) Domestic acquirer re-authorization timeline and risk, (C) Structural alternatives (proxy board, operating agreement) to preserve authorization. MARKET RESEARCH: Identify potential Government-focused acquirers who already have FedRAMP authorization and could integrate without triggering review (other FedRAMP MSPs, defense contractors with cloud authorizations).

uncertainty_register.unknown: UK SOVEREIGN SEGMENT FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND CUSTOMER PIPELINE: Actual UK Sovereign revenue (launched March 2024, revenue unknown but estimated <$135M), customer count and contract values, revenue trajectory (ramping up or stalling?), path to profitability (when does segment cover isolated infrastructure fixed costs?), customer pipeline (how many prospects, conversion rates, competitive win rates vs AWS UK Sovereign and other alternatives), BT partnership terms and costs (if material), total investment to date ($5-15M estimated - what is actual?), board commitment to continue funding vs potential strategic exit if underperforms.
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: UK SOVEREIGN INVESTMENT DECISION: If segment is ramping successfully ($50M revenue in year 1 growing to $100M year 2, $150M year 3 trajectory toward $200-300M at maturity), justifies continued investment and supports growth narrative for overall business. UK Sovereign becomes STRATEGIC ASSET demonstrating Rackspace can build new compliance-moat businesses. If segment is stalling ($10-20M revenue year 1, limited pipeline, losing deals to AWS UK Sovereign), may be STRATEGIC MISTAKE consuming capital and management attention with no payoff. Should cut losses, shut down or sell to UK-focused buyer. If segment break-even timeline is 3-5 years but Rackspace faces financial pressure sooner (debt refinancing, liquidity crisis), board may force premature exit before segment matures, crystallizing investment loss. AFFECTS: (1) Continued investment commitment (board may demand stop loss if performance poor), (2) Valuation (growth segment adds value if successful, subtracts if failing), (3) Management credibility (UK Sovereign is CEO's strategic bet - failure damages leadership confidence), (4) M&A approach (successful UK Sovereign can be sold separately to UK buyer for premium, failed UK Sovereign may have zero value or be abandoned pre-transaction).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: ACCESS: Request from management: (1) UK Sovereign monthly revenue and customer count (March 2024 - present), (2) Customer acquisition: Pipeline size, conversion rates, win/loss analysis (who are we losing to? why?), (3) Financial performance: Revenue, gross margin, operating expenses, EBITDA/operating income (likely deeply negative currently), (4) Profitability projection: At what revenue level does segment break even? What timeline to reach that level under base/bull/bear scenarios? (5) Investment to date: Total capital invested (infrastructure, personnel, sales/marketing), remaining investment required to reach viability, (6) BT partnership: What does BT provide (connectivity, infrastructure, co-marketing)? What does Rackspace pay? Material revenue share or just standard telecom charges? (7) Competitive landscape: AWS UK Sovereign Cloud timeline (when fully operational?), market size estimates (TAM for UK sovereign cloud), (8) Board commitment: What are exit triggers? (e.g., if segment fails to reach $X revenue by end of 2026, board will approve shutdown/sale). DECISION FRAMEWORK: Define success metrics (revenue, customer count, competitive win rate) and timeline milestones. If segment failing to hit milestones, have pre-planned exit strategy ready rather than continuing to fund indefinitely.
